action.action-desc: Ms. Adams (for herself, Mr. Smith of Washington, Ms. Barragán, Mrs. Napolitano, Mr. Conyers, Mr. Aguilar, Ms. Kelly of Illinois, Ms. Judy Chu of California, Ms. Wilson of Florida, Mr. David Scott of Georgia, and Mr. Payne) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce

form.official-title: To authorize the Secretary of Health and Human Services to award grants to support the access of marginalized youth to sexual health services, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Youth Access to Sexual Health Services Act of 2017.

section.header: Authorization of grants to support the access of marginalized youth to sexual health services

subsection.text: The Secretary of Health and Human Services may award grants on a competitive basis to eligible entities to support the access of marginalized youth to sexual health services.
An eligible entity that is awarded a grant under subsection (a) may use the funds to—

paragraph.text: provide medically accurate and complete and age-, developmentally, and culturally appropriate sexual health information to marginalized youth, including information on how to access sexual health services;
promote effective communication regarding sexual health among marginalized youth;
promote and support better health, education, and economic opportunities for school-age parents; and
train individuals who work with marginalized youth to promote—

subparagraph.text: the prevention of unintended pregnancy;
the prevention of sexually transmitted infections, including the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV);
healthy relationships; and
the development of safe and supportive environments.

subsection.text: To be awarded a grant under subsection (a), an eligible entity shall submit an application to the Secretary at such time, in such manner, and containing such information as the Secretary may require.
In awarding grants under subsection (a), the Secretary shall give priority to eligible entities—

paragraph.text: with a history of supporting the access of marginalized youth to sexuality education or sexual health services; and
that plan to serve marginalized youth that are not served by Federal adolescent programs for the prevention of pregnancy, HIV, and other sexually transmitted infections.

subsection.text: The Secretary may not award a grant under subsection (a) to an eligible entity unless—

paragraph.text: such eligible entity has formed a partnership with a community organization; and
such eligible entity agrees—

subparagraph.text: to employ a scientifically effective strategy;
that all information provided to marginalized youth will be—

clause.text: provided in the language and cultural context that is most appropriate for the individuals served by the eligible entity; and

subparagraph.text: that for each year the eligible entity receives grant funds under subsection (a), the eligible entity will submit to the Secretary an annual report that includes—

clause.text: the use of grant funds by the eligible entity;
how the use of grant funds has increased the access of marginalized youth to sexual health services; and
such other information as the Secretary may require.

paragraph.text: Not less than once every two years after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall evaluate the effectiveness of whichever of the following is greater:

subparagraph.text: Eight grants awarded under subsection (a).
Ten percent of the grants awarded under subsection (a).

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall make available to the public—

subparagraph.text: the evaluations required under paragraph (1); and
the reports required under subsection (e)(2)(C).

subsection.text: No funds made available to an eligible entity under this section may be used by such entity to provide access to sexual health services that—

paragraph.text: withhold sexual health-promoting or life-saving information;
are medically inaccurate or have been scientifically shown to be ineffective;
promote gender stereotypes;
are insensitive or unresponsive to the needs of young people, including—

subparagraph.text: youth with varying gender identities, gender expressions, and sexual orientations;
sexually active youth;
pregnant or parenting youth;
survivors of sexual abuse or assault; and
youth of all physical, developmental, and mental abilities; or

paragraph.text: are inconsistent with the ethical imperatives of medicine and public health.

subsection.text: Any unobligated balance of funds made available under section 510(d) of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 710(d)) (as in effect on the day before the date of the enactment of this Act) are hereby transferred and made available to the Secretary to carry out this Act. The amounts transferred and made available to carry out this Act shall remain available until expended.

paragraph.text: The term community organization includes a State or local health or education agency, public school, youth-focused organization that is faith-based and community-based, juvenile justice entity, or other organization that provides confidential and appropriate sexuality education or sexual health services to marginalized youth.

The term eligible entity includes a State or local health or education agency, public school, nonprofit organization, hospital, or an Indian Tribe or Tribal organization (as such terms are defined in section 4 of the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act (25 U.S.C. 5304)).
The term marginalized youth means a person under the age of 26 that is disadvantaged by underlying structural barriers and social inequity.
The term medically accurate and complete, when used with respect to information, means information that—

subparagraph.text: is supported by research and recognized as accurate, objective, and complete by leading medical, psychological, psychiatric, or public health organizations and agencies; and
does not withhold any information relating to the effectiveness and benefits of correct and consistent use of condoms or other contraceptives and pregnancy prevention methods.

paragraph.text: The term scientifically effective strategy means a strategy that—

subparagraph.text: is widely recognized by leading medical and public health agencies as effective in promoting sexual health awareness and healthy behavior; and
either—

clause.text: has been demonstrated to be effective on the basis of rigorous scientific research; or

paragraph.text: The term Secretary means the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
The term sexual health services includes—

subparagraph.text: sexual health information, education, and counseling;
contraception;
emergency contraception;
condoms and other barrier methods to prevent pregnancy or sexually transmitted infections;
routine gynecological care, including human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccines and cancer screenings;
pre-exposure prophylaxis or post-exposure prophylaxis;
mental health services;
sexual assault survivor services; and
other prevention, care, or treatment.
